items.title: Chest Msucle
items.description: The chest muscles, also known as the pectoral muscles, are a group of muscles located in the chest area. They are responsible for several movements of the arm and shoulder, including flexion, adduction, and rotation.

items.title: Bench Press
items.description: Bench press is a popular strength-training exercise that primarily targets the chest muscles, but also works the shoulders and triceps. The exercise is performed lying on a bench with a weighted barbell held above the chest, then lowering the bar down towards the chest and pressing it back up to the starting position.

items.title: Bench Press (Incline)
items.description: Incline bench press is a variation of the traditional bench press exercise that targets the upper portion of the chest muscles. Instead of lying flat on a bench, you would adjust the bench to an incline position, typically between 30 and 45 degrees.

items.title: Bench Press (Decline)
items.description: Decline bench press is another variation of the traditional bench press exercise that targets the lower portion of the chest muscles. In this exercise, the bench is set at a decline angle, typically between 15 and 30 degrees, with the head lower than the feet.

items.title: Dumbbell Press
items.description: Dumbbell press is an exercise that targets the chest muscles, as well as the shoulders and triceps. Unlike the traditional barbell bench press, dumbbell press is performed with dumbbells, which allows for a greater range of motion and can help to improve muscular imbalances.

items.title: Dumbbell Press (Incline)
items.description: Incline dumbbell press is a variation of the traditional bench press exercise that targets the upper portion of the chest muscles. Instead of lying flat on a bench, you would adjust the bench to an incline position, typically between 30 and 45 degrees.

items.title: Dumbbell Press (Decline)
items.description: Decline dumbbell press is another variation of the traditional bench press exercise that targets the lower portion of the chest muscles. In this exercise, the bench is set at a decline angle, typically between 15 and 30 degrees, with the head lower than the feet.
